  • P Ondansetron (Zofran) 4 mg PO if patient is 12 y/o or older and weight is more than or equal to 40 kg.
Paramedic
  • A For pain relief, including with unilateral flank pain, consider 1014 Pain Management Protocol.
  • P For pain relief, call MCP for orders.
  • A For active vomiting, Ondansetron 4 mg slow IV.
  • A For nausea or if no IV access established, Ondansetron (Zofran) 4 mg PO (dissolving tablet) or consider administering 4 mg (2 ml) of the IV form PO by spraying it into the patient's mouth.
  • P Ondansetron 0.1 mg/kg IV (max 4 mg) if patient is 12 y/o or older and weight is more than or equal to 40 kg.

Clinical Pearls

The Paramedic can administer the IV form of Ondansetron orally to adults by spraying it into the patient's mouth.

title: Allergic Reactions/Anaphylaxis
content:
4002.1 General Guidelines

  • Epinephrine is the mainstay of anaphylaxis in allergic reaction treatment.
  • Epinephrine is particularly important in cases of any airway edema, hypotension, or when multiple body systems are involved.
  • Advanced age is not a contraindication to epinephrine.

4002.2 Clinical Management

Treatment Algorithm

EMR
  • Provide O₂ as needed.
  • If allergic reaction:
    • If equal to or greater than 30 kg, give both Adult EpiPen and EpiPen Jr. (adult and pediatric).
    • P If less than 15 kg, EpiPen Jr.
    • P If equal to or greater than 15 kg and less than 30 kg, Adult EpiPen.
  • If applicable, apply ice pack.
  • ♦ If symptoms persist, may repeat Epinephrine (adult and pediatric) in 10 minutes.
  • Call for transport.
EMT
  • If patient develops wheezing, assist them with their prescribed metered dose inhaler or ♦ Albuterol 2.5 mg and Ipratropium 0.5 mg, nebulized with O₂ flowing at 8-10 LPM. May repeat Albuterol 2.5 mg nebulized two times.
  • {If an allergic reaction and an absence of Epi-pens in the drug bag, EMTs are permitted to administer Epinephrine IM via a syringe}.
    • {The EMT may only perform this skill after authorization and training from their Medical Director}.
    • {If equal to or greater than 30 kg, Epinephrine (1:1,000) 0.5 IM, (adult and pediatric)}.
    • {P If equal to or greater than 15 kg and less than 30 kg. Epinephrine (1:1,000) 0.3 mg IM}.
    • {P If less than 15 kg, Epinephrine (1:1,000) 0.15 mg IM}.
    • ♦ {May repeat Epinephrine (1:1,000) 0.5 mg IM after 10 minutes (adult and pediatric)}.
    • ♦ {P May repeat Epinephrine (1:1,000) (at weight appropriate dose) after 10 minutes}.
AEMT
  • If an allergic reaction:
    • If equal to or greater than 30 kg, give both Adult EpiPen and EpiPen Jr or Epi (1:1,000) 0.5 mg IM (adult and pediatric).
    • P If equal to or greater than 15 kg and less than 30 kg. Adult EpiPen or Epinephrine (1:1,000) 0.3 mg IM.
    • P if less than 15 kg, EpiPen Jr or Epinephrine (1:1,000) 0.15 mg IM.
    • May repeat Epinephrine (1:1,000) 0.5 mg IM after 10 minutes (adult and pediatric).
    • P May repeat Epinephrine (1:1,000) (at weight appropriate dose) after 10 minutes.
  • If apneic, intubate, possibly with smaller than normal ET tube.
Paramedic
  • For wheezing, no orders needed for Albuterol 2.5 mg and Ipratropium 0.5 mg, nebulized with O₂ flowing at 8-10 LPM.
  • If patient intubated, Albuterol 2.5 mg by nebulizer into the ETT. If Ipratropium not given before intubation, add to first Albuterol.
  • If hypotensive, IV fluid to maintain adequate BP. P If hypotensive, IV fluid 20 ml/kg IV to maintain adequate BP.
  • A Diphenhydramine 50 mg IM or IV.
  • P Diphenhydramine 1 mg/kg IM or IV (max dose 50 mg).
  • If patient deteriorating or unresponsive, consider early intubation, possibly with a smaller than normal size endotracheal tube.
  • If a conscious patient requires intubation:
    • A Lidocaine 100 mg IN half dose per nostril or added to nebulizer with breathing treatment.
    • P Lidocaine 1.5 mg/kg nebulized with O₂ 8-10 LPM or IN. Maximum dose is 100 mg.
  • If patient remains hypotensive after IV fluid, Epinephrine (1:10,000) 0.1 mg, slow IV, every 3 minutes up to 0.5 mg.
  • A Solu-Medrol 125 mg IV.
  • P Solu-Medrol 2 mg/kg IV, max dose 125 mg.

title: Asthma/Emphysema/COPD
content:
4003.1 Clinical Management

Treatment Algorithm

EMR
  • Provide O₂ as needed.
  • Call for transport.
EMT
  • If patient develops wheezing, assist them with taking their prescribed metered dose inhaler or ♦ Consider Albuterol 2.5 mg and Ipratropium 0.5 mg, nebulized with O₂ flowing at 8-10 LPM. May repeat Albuterol 2.5 mg nebulized two times.
  • For any patient who is bronchial constricted: CPAP.
  • Transport unless ALS intercept is less than 5 minutes.
AEMT
  • No orders needed for Albuterol 2.5 mg and Ipratropium 0.5 mg, nebulized with O₂ flowing at 8-10 LPM.
  • If patient intubated, Albuterol 2.5 mg by nebulizer into the ETT. If Ipratropium not given before intubation, add to first Albuterol.
  • After intubation of an asthma patient, limit rate of ventilation to avoid auto-PEEP and hypotension, provided that you can adequately oxygenate the patient at below rate:
    • A 8-10 breaths per minute for adults.
    • P 10-15 breaths per minute for pediatric patients.
  • Consider needle decompression in the presence of auto-PEEP or hyperinflation:
    • If the patient is in cardiac arrest, perform bilateral needle decompression.
    • If unilateral or bilateral diminished breath sounds and the patient is hemodynamically unstable, consider decompression of only the affected sides.
    • Decompression sites: Second or third intercostal space in the mid-clavicular line (use nipple line as a guide), Fourth or fifth intercostal space in the mid-axillary line.
    • P in patients less than 8 years old, decompression site choice will be limited to the 2nd or 3rd intercostal space at the mid-clavicular line.
  • Asthmatics in severe distress (NOT for emphysema or COPD):
    • If equal to or greater than 30 kg, give both Adult EpiPen and EpiPen Jr or Epi (1:1,000) 0.5 mg IM (adult and pediatric).
    • P If equal to or greater than 15 kg and less than 30 kg. Adult EpiPen or Epinephrine (1:1,000) 0.3 mg IM.
    • P If less than 15 kg, EpiPen Jr or Epinephrine (1:1,000) 0.15 mg IM.
    • May repeat Epinephrine (1:1,000) 0.5 mg IM after 10 minutes (adult and pediatric).
    • P May repeat Epinephrine (1:1,000) (at weight appropriate dose) after 10 minutes.
Paramedic
  • If a conscious patient requires intubation:
    • A Lidocaine 100 mg IN half dose per nostril or added to nebulizer with breathing treatment.
    • P Lidocaine 1.5 mg/kg nebulized with O₂ LPM or IN. Maximum dose is 100 mg.
  • For any persistent bronchial constriction consider CPAP or {Bi-PAP}.
  • A Solu-Medrol 125 mg IV.
  • P Solu-Medrol 2 mg/kg IV, max dose 125 mg.
  • Bronchoconstriction due to asthma refractory to Albuterol, Ipratropium, and Epinephrine:
    • A Magnesium Sulfate 2 gm (half bag) infused with macro-drip tubing over 10 minutes.

title: Behavioral Emergencies
content:
4004.1 General Guidelines

  • Per Ohio Revised Code, EMS providers may not "pink slip" an individual even if they are threatening harm to themselves or others.
  • Only a police officer, crisis worker, health officer, psychiatrist or licensed physician can administer an involuntary admission form ("pink slip") for a patient.
  • Each EMS department, in consultation with its medical director and local law enforcement, should have a procedure to deal with these types of situations.

4004.2 Precautions

  • Consider staging until law enforcement has made the scene safe.
  • Have law enforcement search patient for weapons.
  • Consider possible medical causes for patient's condition.

4004.3 Clinical Management

Treatment Algorithm

EMT
  • Determine patient capacity and consent.
  • Take actions to prevent imminent harm to the patient or others, if it is safe to do so.
  • Do not judge, just treat.
  • Consider possible medical causes for patient's condition.
  • If patient is unwilling to go to a facility, consider whether they are a candidate for a "pink slip".
  • Transport all patients who are not making rational decisions and who are a threat to themselves or others for medical evaluation.
  • A If possible, transport a mental health patient to the facility where the individual has been previously treated.
  • A In all other cases, patients greater than or equal to 18 years old should be transported to the closest ED.
  • P Patients less than 18 years old, with mental health issues should be transported to a facility with pediatric mental health capabilities. (see 4004.5 c. Dayton Children's Hospital for specific instructions).
Paramedic

Severe agitation is a medical emergency, and should be treated. See 4005 Behavioral Emergencies - Combative Patient/Emergency Sedation.

4004.4 Transport Guidelines

  • Adults: Can be transported to any facility. Considerations should be given to the capabilities of the receiving facility, combativeness of the patient and length of transport time.
  • Pediatrics:
    • Transporting pediatric patients to Dayton Children's Hospital should be a priority.
    • For excessive transport times, consider transport to a closer facility which can facilitate transfer after an initial assessment, stabilization, and a consult with DCH.
    • While GMVEMSC Standing Orders consider a pediatric patient to be less than 16 years old, DCH will accept behavioral patients up to the age of 17 years old.
    • Pregnant patients of any age should be transported to an adult facility.

4004.5 Pre-Arrival Notification of Behavioral Patients

  • Premier Health Facilities: Use "ACE Alert".
  • Kettering Health Network Facilities: Use "Dr. White".
  • Dayton Children's Hospital (Main Campus only): Use "ACE Alert".
    • Between 1000-0000 hrs, transport to DCH Mathile Center.
    • Between 0001-0959 hrs, transport to Main Campus ED.
    • Transport to Main Campus ED also for: need for medical care, intoxication, sexual assault, strangulation, patient received Ketamine, pregnancy.

title: Behavioral Emergencies - Combative Patients/Emergency Sedation
content:
4005.1 General Guidelines

  • Restrained patients must not be transported in a prone position with hands & feet behind their back.
  • Restrained patients must not be sandwiched between backboards or other items.
  • Always maintain the ability to remove restraints if the patient vomits or develops respiratory distress.

4005.2 Combative Patients

  • Identified as irrational behavior, examples include aggression, violence, and/or paranoia in the patient.
  • This state can result from causes including, but not limited to: Stimulant intoxication, Psychiatric illness, Hypoglycemia, Other medical illnesses.
  • The combative patient often becomes significantly hyperthermic and/or hypoxic, even after the episode has subsided.

4005.3 Collaboration with Law Enforcement

  • Providers should get as much information as possible from LE as to the reason for the encounter, observed behaviors, medical history, use of force and/or less-than-lethal weapons, etc.
  • Decisions to use pharmacological interventions will be made solely by the EMS provider based on their own assessment and not at the behest of the law enforcement officers on scene.
  • Consideration should be given to transitioning the patient from police restraints to medical restraints prior to transport.
  • If restraint devices require a key, that key should be transported with the patient whenever possible. Provider agencies should work with their law enforcement partners beforehand to establish SOPs to address this concern.

4005.4 Clinical Management

Treatment Algorithm

EMT
  • Explain the need for restraint to the patient.
  • Recheck often a restrained patient's ability to breathe and distal circulation.
Paramedic
  • A Ketamine 250 mg IM (in anterolateral thigh) or Ketamine 100 mg slow IV.
  • A No change after 10 minutes with IM dose or 5 minutes with IV dose, consider additional medication: DO NOT ADMINISTER KETAMINE AND MIDAZOLAM SIMULTANEOUSLY. Give the administered sedative time to work before moving on to a secondary medication and dosing.
    • A Ketamine 250 mg IM (in opposite anterolateral thigh) or repeat Ketamine 100 mg IV.
    • AND/OR
    • A Midazolam 10 mg IN (5 mg in each nostril), or Midazolam 2.5 mg slow IV, or Midazolam 5 mg IM.
    • A If necessary, repeat Midazolam doses: Repeat Midazolam 5 mg IN (2.5 mg in each nostril) after 10 minutes, or repeat Midazolam 2.5 mg slow IV after 5 minutes, or repeat Midazolam 5 mg IM after 10 minutes.
  • P If the patient is age 8 or greater, consider Ketamine 1 mg/kg slow IV (max dose 100 mg) or Ketamine 5 mg/kg IM (max dose 250), OR Midazolam 0.2 mg/kg IN (max IN dose 10 mg) or Midazolam 0.1 mg/kg slow IV (max IV dose 2.5 mg) or Midazolam 0.2 mg/kg IM (max IM dose 4 mg).
  • ♦ Call MCP for additional Ketamine or Midazolam.
  • A If an excited delirium patient goes into arrest: Consider Sodium Bicarbonate 100 mEq IV.

title: Childbirth
content:
4006.1 General Guidelines

  • Obtain history of patient condition and pregnancy, including: Contraction duration and interval, Gestation age, Due date, First day of last menstrual period, Number of pregnancies and live births (gravida/para), Prenatal care, Possibility of multiple births, Any possible complications, Any drug use by the mother.
  • The patient should be transported to a hospital with obstetrical capabilities, unless delivery is imminent (crowning). ABSOLUTELY NO PREGNANT PATIENTS TO DAYTON or CINCINNATI CHILDREN'S HOSPITALS.
  • Visualize the perineal area only when contractions are less than five minutes apart.
  • Run reports must be completed for each patient. The newborn is a separate patient from the mother.

4006.2 Clinical Management

Treatment Algorithm

EMT
  • Apply gentle pressure on the baby's head with a flat hand to prevent an explosive delivery.
  • Place a gloved hand inside the birth canal only in the case of: Breech delivery with entrapped head, or Prolapsed umbilical cord limiting fetal circulation.
  • Keep the newborn warm with blankets and (if available) a head cover.
  • Cut the umbilical cord and then place the baby to suckle at the mother's breast.
AEMT
  • Obtain one, five and ten minute APGAR scores if time and patient condition permit. (see table below)
Paramedic

Establish an IV for patients in active labor.

APGAR Score

APGAR Score012
AppearanceFull body cyanosisCyanosis at the extremitiesNo cyanosis present
PulseAbsentSlow (less than 100)Greater than 100
GrimaceFlaccidGrimace with stimulationCough or sneeze with stimulation
ActivityAbsentSome flexion of extremitiesActive motion
Respiratory EffortAbsentSlow or irregularGood, vigorous cry

title: Childbirth with Complications
content:
4007.1 General Guidelines

  • With all complicated childbirth scenarios, evaluate the need for rapid transport to a birthing center or possibly, the nearest hospital.
  • These guidelines apply to all levels of certification, except where noted.
  • In all complicated childbirth scenarios, place the mother on oxygen by non-rebreather mask.

4007.2 Clinical Management

a. Cord around Baby's Neck:

  • As baby's head passes out of the vaginal opening, feel for the cord.
  • Initially try to slip cord over baby's head.
  • If too tight, clamp cord in two places and cut between clamps.

b. Breech Delivery:

  • When an appendage or buttocks first becomes visible, position patient to discourage delivery, coach patient to avoid pushing and transport patient immediately.
  • If the delivery is in progress, take care to support the baby's body.
  • If the head is caught in the birth canal:
    1. Apply gentle pressure above the pubis symphysis as the mother pushes.
    2. If the head will not deliver, you must create an airway for the baby.
    3. Support the body and insert two fingers into the birth canal, forming a "V" around the mouth and nose.

c. Prolapsed Cord:

  • When the umbilical cord is exposed prior to delivery, check cord for pulse.
  • Transport immediately with hips elevated and a moist dressing around cord.
  • Insert two fingers into the birth canal to displace the presenting part away from cord, distribute pressure evenly if occiput presents.
  • Do not attempt to reinsert cord.

d. Excessive Bleeding:

  • Treat for shock.
  • Post-delivery, massage uterus firmly and put baby to mother's breast.
  • The AEMT and Paramedic may consider the use of Tranexamic Acid (TXA) 2 grams IV/IO over 1-2 minutes as outlined in 3015 Hemorrhage Control.

title: Diabetic  Emergencies - Hypoglycemia
content:
4008.1 General Guidelines

  • Hypoglycemia is defined as a blood glucose level less than 60 mg/dL, or there is strong suspicion of hypoglycemia despite glucometer readings.
  • Hyperglycemia is defined as a blood glucose level at or above 250 mg/dL. EMS will treat patients with a BGL greater than 400 mg/dL or when the glucometer reads "High".

4008.2 Clinical Management

Treatment Algorithm

EMR
  • Provide basic care.
  • Call for transport.
EMT
  • Obtain blood sample via finger stick and measure blood glucose level.
  • If Hypoglycemic: Administer 1 tube of Oral Glucose.
  • Maintain normothermia. Unconscious diabetics are often hypothermic.
AEMT
  • In a diabetic patient with an insulin pump and blood glucose less than 60 mg/dL, treat the hypoglycemia.
  • Monitor and transport.
Paramedic
  • If Hypoglycemic:
    • A Administer Dextrose 10% (D10), 250 ml at wide open rate, (250 ml = 25 g of Dextrose).
    • P Administer Dextrose 10% (D10) 5 ml/kg, maximum single dose of 250 ml.
    • For newborn, Dextrose 10% (D10) 2 ml/kg if BGL is less than 40 mg/dL.
    • Dextrose 10% (D10) may be repeated in ten minutes if blood sugar remains less than 60 mg/dL.
  • If Hyperglycemic:
    • A If BGL reads over 400 mg/dL or "High" on glucometer, administer 500 ml fluid IV - wide open.
    • Do not administer fluid to a hyperglycemic pediatric patient, unless otherwise indicated.
    • A If an excited delirium patient goes into arrest: Consider Sodium Bicarbonate 100 mEq IV.

title: Diabetic Emergencies - Refusal of Transport
content:
4009.1 General Guidelines

  • EMTs and above may allow for diabetic patients to refuse transport after treatment.
  • EMRs should call for transport or a provider of a higher-level certification.

4009.2 Refusal Procedures

  • Patients 18 years of age or older may be permitted to refuse. Follow these guidelines:
    • Repeat physical examination and vital signs.
    • Patient must be Alert & Oriented x3.
    • Warn the patient that there is a significant risk of going back into a hypoglycemic state, especially if on oral hypoglycemics.
    • Advise the patient to eat something substantial immediately.
    • Advise the patient to contact their family physician as soon as possible to minimize future episodes.
    • Advise the patient to stay with someone.
    • Follow normal patient refusal procedures.
  • If the diabetic patient is under 18, but a parent or guardian is present, then the responsible adult may refuse patient transportation under the same guidelines as listed above in 4009.2.a.

title: Extrapyramidal Reactions
content:
4010.1 General Guidelines

  • A patient who is currently on a phenothiazine (e.g., Phenergan, Thorazine, Compazine) or a butyrophenone (e.g., Haldol, Droperidol) and exhibiting signs of acute muscle spasm or motor restlessness may be suffering from an Extrapyramidal Reaction.
  • Extrapyramidal reactions can occur with ingestion of recreational drugs.
  • Physical examination findings may include any of the following: Oculogyric crisis, Buccolingual crisis, Trismus, Difficulty in speaking, Facial grimacing, Torticollis crisis, Opisthotonus, Tortipelvic crisis. Mental status is unaffected. Vital signs are usually normal.

4010.2 Clinical Management

Treatment Algorithm

EMR
  • Provide basic care.
  • Call for transport.
EMT

If blood glucose less than 60, or there is strong suspicion of hypoglycemia despite glucometer readings, then follow 4008 Diabetic Emergencies - Hypoglycemia protocol.

AEMT
  • Initiate IV fluid to maintain adequate BP.
  • ♦
    • A Diphenhydramine 50 mg IV or IM.
    • P Diphenhydramine 1 mg/kg IV or IM (max dose 50 mg).
Paramedic
  • A Diphenhydramine 50 mg IV or IM.
  • P Diphenhydramine 1 mg/kg IV or IM (max dose 50 mg).

title: Obstetrical Emergencies
content:
4011.1 General Guidelines

  • Consider the possibility of ectopic pregnancy in females of child-bearing age.
  • Ask for first day of last menstrual period.
  • Gestational age should be expressed in weeks whenever possible.
  • Aggressively treat for hypovolemic shock (do not rely on standard vital sign parameters).
  • Give psychological support to patient and family.
  • Be sure to take all expelled tissue with you to the hospital.

4011.2 Transport Decisions

  • Transport to Maternity Department if: Pregnant patients, 20 weeks, or greater gestation with obstetric complaints. If unsure of time of gestation, then consider transport to a maternity department.
  • Transport to Emergency Department if: Pregnant patients with minor trauma or medical (non-obstetric) complaints. Pregnant patients less than 20 weeks gestation.
  • Pregnant trauma patients should be rapidly transported to the Emergency Department at an Adult Trauma Center with labor and delivery capabilities.
  • Positional transport considerations: Prepare for postural hypotension. Place in left lateral recumbent position or place a pillow under the right hip/lower back. Apply continuous manual displacement of the uterus towards the patient's left side.

4011.3 Clinical Management

  • Causes of cardiac arrest in pregnant patients can include: Pulmonary embolism, Trauma, Hemorrhage, Congenital or acquired cardiac disease.
  • Load and go to the closest hospital and follow all cardiac arrest protocols enroute.

4011.4 Aspirin and the Pregnant Patient

Aspirin is contraindicated in third trimester due to possibility of pre and post-partum hemorrhaging and protentional fetal harm.

title: Overdose/Poisonings
content:
General Guidelines

  • EMS personnel should contact and confer with MCP for direction on suspected poisonings.
  • Poison Control is intended for use by the general public.
  • If possible, provide receiving facility all available information about the substance:
    • Safety data sheets (SDS)
    • The container (if it is safe to do so)
    • The label or an image of the label and warning information if it is unsafe or unpractical to transport the actual substance container
  • See Clinical Pearls for recommendations on treatment for button battery ingestion.

Clinical Management

Pediatric Considerations

  • Most pediatric patients with respiratory depression do not have narcotic overdose. They are either septic or have respiratory failure.
  • Treatment for button battery ingestion is for patients greater to or equal to 12 months of age.

Signs & Symptoms

  • Mental status changes
  • Hypo/hypertension
  • Decreased respiratory rate
  • Tachycardia or bradycardia
  • Cardiac dysrhythmias
  • Seizures

Treatment Algorithm

EMR / EMT

  • If respirations are impaired or there is suspicion of narcotic overdose:
  • Adult: Administer Naloxone, up to 4 mg IN (half dose per nostril). May repeat Naloxone doses in 2 minutes.
  • Pediatric Naloxone:
    • Less than or equal to 20 kg then 0.1 mg/kg IN, (max dose 2 mg), may repeat x one.
    • Greater than 20 kg: 2 mg, IN, may repeat as needed.
  • Titrate Naloxone to adequate respirations.
  • Consider patient restraint before administration of Naloxone.

AEMT

  • If patient has a pulse, Naloxone should be administered before inserting an ETT.
  • When given IV or IN, the onset of action for Naloxone is approximately 2 minutes.
  • If respirations are impaired or there is suspicion of narcotic overdose:
  • Adult: Administer Naloxone, up to 4 mg IN, 2mg IV or 4 mg IM. May repeat Naloxone doses in 2 minutes. Consider repeat IV dosing if no or inadequate response is noted.
  • Pediatric Naloxone:
    • Less than or equal to 20 kg then 0.1 mg/kg IN, IV, IM (max dose 2 mg), may repeat x one.
    • Greater than 20 kg: 2 mg, IN, IV, IM, may repeat as needed.
    • Naloxone slow IV is preferred, but it may be given IN or IM before IV is established.
    • If using IN route and respirations don't improve after 2 minutes, establish IV and administer IV dose.
  • Titrate to adequate respirations.

Paramedic

  • Follow AEMT guidelines for Naloxone administration.
  • Stimulant Overdose (cocaine, methamphetamines, etc.) with chest pain:
    • Adult: Nitroglycerin 0.4 mg SL, if SBP >100, every 5 minutes to a total of three doses.
    • Adult: Midazolam 10 mg, IN (5 mg in each nostril) or 2.5 mg slow IV, or 5 mg IM.
    • Repeat Midazolam 5 mg IN (2.5 mg in each nostril) or 2.5 mg slow IV or 5 mg IM for unrelieved chest pain.
    • For patients greater than 69 y/o, reduce dosing for sedatives and analgesics to one half of the adult doses.
  • Tricyclic Antidepressant Overdose: (May be evidenced by bradycardia, tachycardia, hypotension and prolonged QRS)
    • Adult: Sodium Bicarbonate 100 mEq, slow IV. May repeat 50 mEq, slow IV for persistent QRS prolongation.
    • Pediatric: Sodium Bicarbonate 1 mEq/kg slow IV. May repeat 0.5 mEq/kg slow IV for persistent QRS prolongation.
  • Calcium Channel Blocker Overdose:
    • Adult: Calcium Chloride, 1 Gm slow IV.
    • Pediatric: Calcium Chloride, 0.2 ml/kg (20 mg/kg) slow IV (max dose 500 mg).

Consult

  • For guidance on suspected poisonings contact MCP.
  • Calcium Channel Blocker, Beta Blocker and Tricyclic antidotes in this protocol are by MCP order only.

Clinical Pearls

  • Consider other causes of altered mental status such as hypoglycemia, head trauma, sepsis, and stroke.
  • When Naloxone is given intranasal (IN), the onset of action is approximately 2 minutes.
  • Naloxone is not felt to be effective in the reversal of cardiac arrest from opioid overdose. Airway control, ventilation, and quality CPR are still the mainstay of treatment.
  • Naloxone is not indicated in the management of newborns as it can cause withdrawal and secondary issues.
  • Ondansetron (Zofran) is NOT to be given prophylactically with Naloxone.
  • For ingestion of lithium button batteries: If honey is at the scene, patients > 12 months old may be given ~10 ml every 10 minutes (up to 6 times) to coat the battery. Document as "self or family administered".

Medication Examples

Tricyclic Antidepressant Examples:

  • Amitriptyline (Elavil, Endep)
  • Nortriptyline (Pamelor, Aventyl)
  • Amoxapine (Asendin)
  • Clomipramine (Anafranil)
  • Desipramine (Norpramine)
  • Doxepin (Sinequan)
  • Imipramine (Tofranil)
  • Protriptyline (Vivactil)
  • Trimipramine (Surmontil)

Calcium Channel Blocker examples:

  • Amlodipine (Norvasc)
  • Diltiazem (Cardizem)
  • Felodipine (Plendil)
  • Isradipine (Dynacirc)
  • Nifedipine (Procardia, Adalat)
  • Verapamil (Calan, Isoptin)

Beta Blocker examples

  • Acebutolol (Sectral)
  • Atenolol (Tenormin)
  • Carvedilol (Coreg)
  • Labetalol (Normodyne, Trandate)
  • Metoprolol (Toprol, Lopressor)
  • Nadolol (Corgard)
  • Pindolol (Viskin)
  • Propranolol (Inderal)
  • Sotalol (Betapace)
  • Timolol (Blocadren)

title: Respiratory Distress/Pulmonary Edema
content:
General Guidelines

  • This protocol is for patients with respiratory distress secondary to pulmonary edema.
  • For patients with wheezing, see Medical Protocol 4003 - Asthma/COPD/Emphysema.

Clinical Management

Signs & Symptoms

  • Cyanosis
  • Clammy skin
  • Presence/Absence of fever
  • Coughing
  • Wheezing
  • Labored breathing
  • Diaphoresis
  • Pitting edema
  • Bilateral lower lobe rales
  • Tachypnea
  • Apprehension
  • Jugular vein distension (JVD)
  • Inability to talk

Differential Diagnosis

  • Myocardial infarction
  • Congestive heart failure
  • Asthma
  • Anaphylaxis
  • Aspiration
  • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
  • Pleural effusion
  • Pneumonia
  • Pulmonary embolus
  • Pericardial tamponade

Treatment Algorithm

EMT

  • Position patient upright with legs dependent, as tolerated.
  • Administer Oxygen to maintain SpO2 > 94%.
  • If patient exhibits signs of severe respiratory distress, apply CPAP.
  • Assist patient with their own prescribed Nitroglycerin, if SBP is greater than 100 mmHg.

AEMT

  • Administer Nitroglycerin 0.4 mg SL every 5 minutes as long as SBP remains > 100 mmHg.
  • Establish IV access.

Paramedic

  • If SBP is greater than 100 mmHg, administer Nitroglycerin 0.4 mg SL every 5 minutes. There is no maximum dose as long as SBP remains above 100 mmHg.
  • If patient is in severe respiratory distress, consider IV Nitroglycerin if available and trained.

Clinical Pearls

  • Evaluate breath sounds:
    • Clear: treat cause (e.g. MI, pulmonary embolism, metabolic disturbance, and hyperventilation).
    • Wheezes: treat cause (e.g. pulmonary edema, FBAO, asthma, allergic reaction).
    • Rales: treat cause (e.g. pulmonary edema, pneumonia).
    • Diminished or absent:
      • Unilateral: treat cause (e.g., pneumothorax, hemothorax, pneumonia, surgically removed lung).
      • Bilateral: treat cause (e.g., respiratory failure, COPD, asthma).
  • Pneumonia may look like CHF with pulmonary edema. However, the pneumonia patient is often dehydrated and has an elevated temperature.

title: Seizures
content:
Clinical Management

Signs & Symptoms

  • Decreased mental status
  • Sleepiness
  • Incontinence
  • Observed seizure activity
  • Evidence of trauma

Differential Diagnosis

  • Head trauma
  • Tumor
  • Metabolic, hepatic or renal failure
  • Hypoxia
  • Electrolyte abnormality
  • Drugs, medications
  • Infection/fever
  • Alcohol withdrawal
  • Eclampsia
  • Stroke/TIA
  • Hyperthermia
  • Psychogenic Non-epileptic Seizures

Pediatric Considerations

None

Treatment Algorithm

EMR
  • BVM and nasopharyngeal airway during seizure as needed.
  • Maintain normothermia.
EMT
  • Obtain Pulse Oximeter and Capnography reading.
  • If glucose less than 60, or there is strong suspicion of hypoglycemia despite glucometer readings, then follow 4008 Hypoglycemia/Hyperglycemia.
  • Place patient in the recovery position during assessment and transport.
AEMT
  • Cardiac monitor
  • For actively seizing adult patients:
    • For patients greater than 69 y/o, reduce dosing for sedatives and analgesics to one half ( ) of the adult doses
    • Midazolam 10 mg IN (5 mg in each nostril), or Midazolam 2.5 mg slow IV, or Midazolam 5 mg IM
    • If still seizing, repeat Midazolam doses:
      • Repeat Midazolam 5 mg IN (2.5 mg in each nostril) after 10 minutes.
      • Or repeat Midazolam 2.5 mg slow IV after 5 minutes.
      • Or repeat Midazolam 5 mg IM after 10 minutes.
  • For actively seizing pediatric patients:
    • Midazolam 0.2 mg/kg IN (max IN dose 10 mg) or Midazolam 0.1 mg/kg slow IV (max IV dose 2.5 mg) or Midazolam 0.2 mg/kg IM (max IM dose 5 mg)
    • If still seizing, repeat Midazolam doses:
      • Repeat Midazolam 0.2 mg/kg IN (max IN dose 5 mg) after 10 minutes
      • Or repeat Midazolam 0.1 mg/kg slow IV (max IV dose 2.5 mg) after 5 minutes
      • Or repeat Midazolam 0.2 mg/kg IM (max IM dose 5 mg) after 10 minutes
Paramedic
  • If seizing pregnant patient with gestation greater than 20 weeks or postpartum less than 6 weeks, administer Magnesium Sulfate 4 grams (whole bag) infused with macro-drip tubing over 20 min.
  • If seizing pregnant or postpartum patient is less than 16 years old but meets criteria above, then administer Magnesium Sulfate 4 grams (whole bag) infused with macro-drip tubing over 20 min

Consult

None

Clinical Pearls

  • When obtaining history be sure to include the following:
    • Description of seizures, areas of body involved, and duration
    • Other known medical history (e.g., head injury, diabetes, drugs, alcohol, stroke, heart disease, recent fever or illness, possible toxicological agents)

title: Sepsis
content:
4015.1 General Guidelines

  • Severe sepsis is characterized by poor perfusion, leading to a buildup of serum lactate and resulting metabolic acidosis. To compensate, patients increase their minute ventilation, which "blows off" carbon dioxide and lowers EtCO₂.
  • EtCO₂ levels decline in the setting of both poor perfusion and metabolic acidosis.
  • Sepsis is often associated with a high mortality rate. The key to improve patient outcomes is early recognition, fluid resuscitation, O₂ therapy and rapid transport.

4015.2 Clinical Management

Signs & Symptoms

Known or suspected infection. EtCO₂ less than 32 or greater than 47 with 2 or more of the following criteria:

  • Respiratory rate ≥ 22
  • Altered mental status (GCS < 13)
  • Temperature over 100.4°F (38°C) or under 96.8°F (36°C)
  • Heart rate > 90
  • Systolic BP < 100 or Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP) below 65

Treatment Algorithm

EMR
  • Administer oxygen.
  • Call for transport immediately.
EMT

If possible, obtain blood sample via finger stick and measure blood glucose level.

AEMT

♦ Administer a bolus of 1 liter of IV fluid.

Paramedic

For additional fluid administration:

A Consider Norepinephrine by adding 4 mg to 250 ml of IV fluids. Infuse starting at 30 drops per minute (max 45 drops) with 60 drop tubing and titrate to effect. Increase by 5 drops/minute every 5 minutes.

title: Shock
content:
4016.1 General Guidelines

  • Shock is inadequate tissue perfusion.
  • Be proactive in treatment of shock. Do not wait for symptoms to present.
  • Management of shock should include trying to find and correct the underlying cause (if possible).

4016.2 Clinical Management

Treatment Algorithm

EMR
  • Call for transport immediately.
  • Provide O₂ as appropriate.
  • Keep patient warm.
EMT
  • Control external bleeding and treat for hypovolemic shock as indicated.
  • Transport immediately unless ALS intercept is less than 5 minutes.
AEMT
  • Only give fluids for specific signs and symptoms of shock and not to every trauma patient.
  • For persistent shock, establish additional vascular access.
  • Non-traumatic shock without Pulmonary Edema:
    • A IV fluid 500 ml IV. Maintain adequate perfusion.
    • P IV fluid 20 ml/kg IV. Titrate to maintain adequate perfusion.
    • A Additional IV fluid 500 ml IV, if needed.
    • P Additional IV fluid 20 ml/kg IV if needed.
  • Non-traumatic shock with Pulmonary Edema:
    • A Consider IV fluid 250 ml IV.
  • Exsanguinating Hemorrhage:
    • A IV fluid to maintain approximately 100 SBP or a radial pulse. Do not allow blood pressure to get too high.
    • P IV fluid 20 ml/kg IV. May repeat x 2. Titrate to maintain adequate perfusion.
Paramedic

For non-traumatic shock:

  • A Treat arrhythmias as indicated.
  • A If SBP remains less than 100, begin Norepinephrine by adding 4 mg to 250 ml of IV fluids. Infuse starting at 30 drops per minute (max 45 drops) with 60 drop tubing and titrate to effect. Increase by 5 drops/minute every 5 minutes.

title: Stroke
content:
4017.1 General Guidelines

  • If one or more signs of the Cincinnati Prehospital Stroke Scale (CPSS) are abnormal, and less than 24 hours since patient was last seen normal, call a "Stroke Alert", and transport to the closest appropriate Stroke Center.
  • Providers should screen for large vessel occlusions (LVO) before making transport destination decisions.
  • If greater than 24 hours since last known well, consider transport to a Comprehensive or Thrombectomy Capable facility.
  • When reporting last known well, state actual clock time.
  • Agencies may use alternative stroke screening scales (RACE, MEND, LAPSS, etc.) and make transport destination decisions based on their proximity to stroke management facilities with Medical Director approval.

4017.2 Clinical Management

Treatment Algorithm

EMR
  • Perform a Cincinnati Pre-hospital Stroke Scale (or alternative) assessment.
  • A patient in respiratory distress with pale, moist skin and altered mental status should get oxygen via NRB mask.
  • Be prepared to assist ventilations with OPA/NPA and Bag-valve-mask.
  • If signs of cerebral herniation are present, ventilate at: A Approx. 20 times/min, or P 10 faster than normal rate. {If numeric EtCO₂ available, maintain ~30 mmHg}. Never ventilate at less than 8 per minute.
  • A patient with indications of stroke with a SpO₂ less than 94%, should be given oxygen via NC and titrated to 94%. If SpO₂ > 94%, they should not get oxygen.
EMT
  • The presence of a single abnormal finding in the CPSS should dictate a stroke alert and transport to the closest stroke center (unless contraindicated).
  • Perform a Large Vessel Occlusion (LVO) screening looking for: Difficulty in balance or gait, Eye deviation, Visual disturbances, Aphasia, Denial/Neglect.
  • Consider the following contradictions to thrombolytics: Neurosurgery, head trauma or stroke in the last 3 months; Major surgery or serious non-head trauma in previous 14 days; History of GI/urinary tract hemorrhage within 21 days; Current (within 48 hours) use of anticoagulants.
AEMT
  • Patients with onset greater than 24 hours, clinical findings indicative of LVO or with contraindications to thrombolytics consider transport to a Comprehensive Stroke Center or Thrombectomy Capable Facility.
  • Patients with signs or symptoms that strongly indication a possible hemorrhagic stroke should not be transported to a Thrombectomy Capable Facility.
  • Transport the patient with the bed flat, if able to tolerate. If showing signs of increased ICP, do not lay patient flat.
  • If glucose is less than 60, or there is strong suspicion of hypoglycemia despite glucometer readings, then follow 4008 Diabetic Emergencies - Hypoglycemia protocol.

4017.3 Stroke Centers

  • Telemedicine Stroke Center: Drip and ship, has thrombolytic capabilities and immediate access to a Neurologist via telemedicine.
  • Primary Stroke Center: Facility with capability to administer thrombolytics and has an ICU.
  • Comprehensive Stroke Centers or Thrombectomy Capable: Facilities with 24/7 endovascular capabilities.
    • Miami Valley Hospital (Comprehensive)
    • Kettering (Comprehensive)
    • Mercy Health - Springfield (Thrombectomy Capable)

title: Brief Resolved Unexplained Event
content:
5001.1 General Guidelines

  • A Brief Resolved Unexplained Event (BRUE) involves any infant under 1 year of age reported by a bystander as sudden, brief (less than 1 minute), unexplained, and completely resolved upon EMS arrival that includes one or more of the following: Breathing change, Color change, Change in muscle tone, Altered level of responsiveness.
  • Children who experience a BRUE event often have a normal exam on assessment. A cause will be difficult to determine in most BRUE cases.

5001.2 Important Information to Gather

  • Document the symptoms of the event given by the observer: Was the child apneic, cyanotic, or limp? Infant’s color, respirations, and muscle tone. Was seizure-like activity noted? Was any resuscitation attempted? How long did the event last?
  • Obtain past pertinent medical history: Recent trauma, infection, GERD, congenital heart disease, seizures, medication history, birth defects.

5001.3 Clinical Management

  • Support airway, breathing, circulation. Keep warm.
  • Head-to-Toe exam for trauma, bruising, or skin lesions.
  • Check anterior fontanel: is it bulging, flat or sunken?
  • Pupillary exam.
  • Respiratory exam for rate, pattern, work of breathing and lung sounds.
  • Cardiovascular exam symmetry of brachial and femoral pulses.
  • Neuro exam for level of consciousness.
  • Observe for repetition of reported occurrences.
  • The patient should be transported to the hospital for further assessment.

5001.4 Management and Transport of Febrile Pediatric Patients

Transport all infants less than 2 months of age with a history or reported temperature of greater than 38.0 C (100.4 F) or less than 35.6 C (96.0 F).

title: Newborn Care and Resuscitation
content:
5002.1 General Guidelines

  • Maintain airway. Place in the sniffing position (1” towel under shoulders).
  • If drying and suctioning has not provided enough tactile stimulation, flick the infant’s feet or rub the infant’s back.
  • Suction only infants in distress, until airway is clear of all secretions. Bulb suctioning is preferred.
  • If meconium staining is present: If newborn is vigorous, monitor and maintain patent airway. If depressed with poor respiratory effort, decreased muscle tone, or HR < 100, clear the airway by suctioning before other resuscitative steps.
  • Avoid direct application of cool oxygen to infant’s facial area.
  • If stimulation does not improve breathing, then BVM assist may be necessary.

5002.2 Viable Fetus

  • If the fetus is greater than 23 weeks gestation, follow normal resuscitative procedures.
  • A fetus is viable if: Eyelids not fused, and if measurable or known, must be greater 500 grams.

5002.3 Clinical Management

Treatment Algorithm

EMT
  • After delivery of the infant; Assess the airway and breathing.
  • Warm, dry and stimulate.
  • Position head lower than body.
  • Ventilate with BVM at 40-60/minute to increase HR (if less than 100) or for apnea or persistent central cyanosis.
  • If heart rate is less than 60 bpm begin CPR. Compress at 120/min. Compression to Ventilation ratio of 3:1.
AEMT

Obtain APGAR scores at 1, 5 and 10 minutes post-delivery.

Paramedic
  • P If hypovolemic, IV fluid 10 ml/kg over 5-10 minutes.
  • P NEWBORN: D10 (2 ml/kg) if blood glucose less than 40.
  • If heart rate remains less than 60 bpm after CPR:
    • P Epinephrine 1:10,000, 0.01 mg/kg IV.
    • P If no response, repeat Epinephrine 1:10,000, 0.01 mg/kg IV, every 3-5 minutes.

title: Pediatric Assessment Triangle
content:
5003.1 General Guidelines

  • The Pediatric Assessment Triangle establishes a level of severity, assists in determining urgency for life support measures, and identifies key physiological problems using observational & listening skills.
  • This assessment tool can be utilized by providers of all certification levels.

5003.2 Appearance

Appearance reflects adequacy of: oxygenation ventilation, brain perfusion, CNS function. The mnemonic used is TICLS:

  • Tone - Moves spontaneously, sits or stands (age appropriate)
  • Interaction - Alert, interacts with environment
  • Consolability - Stops crying with comfort measures
  • Look/gaze – Makes eye contact, tracks objects
  • Speech/cry – Uses age-appropriate speech or crying

5003.3 Work of Breathing

  • WOB is a more accurate indicator of oxygenation and ventilation than respiratory rate or breath sounds.
  • Assess for effort in breathing, accessory muscle use, and depth of breathing.
  • Capillary refill is an accurate predictor of pediatric oxygenation.

5003.4 Circulation

  • Circulation reflects adequacy of cardiac output and perfusion of vital organs.
  • Cyanosis reflects decreased oxygen levels, vasoconstriction, and respiratory failure.
  • Mottling of the skin indicates hypoxemia, vasoconstriction, and respiratory failure.

title: Safe Harbor
content:
5004.1 General Guidelines

  • Safe Harbor is for the voluntary separation of newborn infant.
  • It is designed to allow desperate parents to separate from their babies to hospitals, EMS, or law enforcement agencies, confidentially.

5004.2 Clinical Management

  • Stipulations of separation:
    • Infant can be no older than be 30 days old.
    • Infant can have no signs of abuse or neglect.
  • History which should be obtained:
    • Date and time of birth
    • Any pertinent family medical history
    • Information regarding prenatal care
    • Information concerning the birth.
  • Information should be obtained in a manner, which will not lead to the revealing of the identity of the parents.
  • Information collected should be based on patient (infant) care needs and assure confidentiality.
  • Transport the infant to the hospital.

title: General Management for Haz Mat
content:
6001.1 General Guidelines

  • This section will provide the responders with direction toward the management and mitigation of Hazardous Material events.
  • The initial goal of any hazardous materials release is to isolate and identify.

6001.2 Initial Actions

  • Personnel safety: Consider potential for secondary devices, Don appropriate PPE, Stage personnel & equipment.
  • Call for additional resources (Haz Mat Teams, Decon crews, Law Enforcement, etc.).
  • Field decontamination: Remove all contaminated clothing, thoroughly wash the patient with {Dawn} dishwashing detergents, pay special attention to skin folds. If contaminated with fuel, irrigate well.
  • Contact Medical Control and the hospital immediately. Provide: Estimated number of patients, signs and symptoms, name of contaminant if known, form of contaminant, and routes of exposure. Obtain permission from hospital before entering with a potentially contaminated patient or crew.
  • ♦ In the event of an MCI involving cyanide or nerve agents, request an “Antidote free” order, allowing you to treat all patients on the scene with the appropriate antidote, rather than calling for patient orders individually.
  • Do not transport a patient until gross decontamination is completed.
  • Decontaminate EMS vehicles prior to leaving hospital.

title: Antidote Resources
content:
6002.1 Antidote Options

  • {EMS Departments are authorized to stockpile Atropine, 2-PAM, auto-injectors, and antidote delivery supplies at their own expense}.
  • Dayton MMRS Caches: Stores additional supplies of cyanide antidotes in each county. To obtain, call 937-333-USAR (8727).
  • CHEMPACK Resources: Store of antidotes to treat about 500 victims of a nerve agent or organophosphate incident.
    • EMS CHEMPACK contents: Atropine, Pralidoxime Chloride (2-PAM), Midazolam or Diazepam (Valium).
    • Hospital CHEMPACK contents: Same drugs, more multi-dose vials.
    • Limitations: Only for nerve agents or organophosphates and when other resources are inadequate.
    • Procurement: ♦ Obtain MCP approval, then contact OSP Central Dispatch at 866-599-LERP (5377) and request a CHEMPACK. You must indicate the agent is identified (or patients show S/S) and the need exceeds available resources.

title: Hazardous Drug Exposure
content:
6003.1 Identification or Recognition of a Hazardous Drug Situation

  • Hazardous drug situations include: Patients who have had IV chemotherapy within 48 hours, patients on oral chemo drugs, or patients with continuous IV chemo at home.
  • Potential routes of exposure include: Absorption, accidental injection, inhalation, ingestion.
  • Don PPE when handling leakage, disposing of drugs, handling body fluids of a patient who received hazardous drugs in the past 48 hours, or cleaning spills.

6003.2 Guidelines for Personal Protective Equipment:

  • Gloves: Two sets of nitrile gloves are recommended. Change gloves every 30 minutes.
  • Disposable, non-permeable gowns.
  • NIOSH-approved respirator masks.
  • Eye and face protection: Wear a face shield whenever there is a possibility of splashing.

6003.3 Procedures:

  • Wipe up liquids with an absorbent pad or spill-control pillow.
  • If necessary, consult with the appropriate Haz-Mat team.
  • Dispose of hazardous drugs or contaminated materials per MSDS or Haz Mat Team direction.
  • Report and document spills as required.
  • For accidental skin exposure: Remove contaminated garments and immediately wash contaminated skin with soap and water.
  • For accidental eye exposure: Immediately flush eye with saline solution or water for at least 30 minutes or until patient transport is completed.

title: Hydrofluoric Acid Exposure
content:
6004.1 Clinical Management

Treatment Algorithm

EMR
  • Ensure the safety of all responders.
  • Begin decontamination and irrigate the chemical burn with water as quickly as possible.
  • Flush affected eyes and skin with copious amounts of water or IV Fluids for a minimum of 30 minutes, or until transport is completed.
  • If ingested, do not induce vomiting. Dilute with water or milk.
  • Monitor for cardiac arrest.
EMT

{Perform a 12-lead EKG and transmit it to the hospital}.

AEMT
  • Intubate if apneic.
  • Consider 1014 Pain Management Protocol.
Paramedic
  • When feasible, use {Epsom Salt solution} as an additional irrigating solution for affected skin. Not for eyes or mucous membranes. Do not delay water irrigation.
  • If ingested, in addition to water or milk, give {3-4 ounces of magnesium-containing antacid (i.e., Maalox or Mylanta)}.
  • Intubate if unconscious or at first sign of pulmonary edema or respiratory distress.
  • Perform a 12-lead EKG and monitor for prolonged QT interval.
  • Apply {magnesium-containing antacid (Maalox or Mylanta)} topically to burned areas. Omit if topical agents have already been applied.
  • ♦ If patient with HF exposure experiences tetany or cardiac arrest, administer Calcium Chloride 10% 1 g (10 ml) 10%, IV. This should be considered a first line drug in cardiac arrest associated with Hydrofluoric Acid.
  • ♦ If patient was exposed to high concentration HF (> 40%), discuss prophylactic Calcium Chloride 10% 400 mg (4 ml), slow IV with MCP.

title: Organophosphate Exposure
content:
6005.1 Clinical Management

Treatment Algorithm

EMR
  • Administer oxygen.
  • ♦ Administer Atropine by DouDote every 5 minutes, as available until the lungs are clear to auscultation. Can be given to adult and pediatric (>40 kgs) patients.
Paramedic
  • ♦ Treat seizures with Midazolam or Diazepam. G For patients > 69 y/o, reduce dosing to one half (½).
  • ♦ Administer Atropine every 5 minutes (up to 3 doses), as available until lungs are clear.
    • A Adults and children > 40 kgs, give DuoDote, or Atropine 2 mg, IV, IM.
    • P Children 20–40 kg, give 1.0 mg Atropine, or the 1.0 mg AtroPen auto-injector.
    • P Children < 20 kg, give 0.5 mg Atropine, or the 0.5 mg AtroPen auto-injector.
  • A ♦ Follow Atropine with 2-PAM (Pralidoxime) 600 mg IM.
  • P ♦ Infants and young children should recieve Pralidoxime, 25-50 mg/kg IV or IM, if available.
  • Treat seizures with Midazolam or Diazepam.

title: Drug Bag Program: General Operating Guidelines
content:
7001.1 Drug Bag Exchange Committee Make-up

  • Co-Chairpersons: One Hospital EMS coordinator and One Hospital pharmacy representative or one Greater Miami Valley EMS Council member.
  • Members: EMS Coordinator and Pharmacy representative from each participating hospital, and any interested GMVEMSC member.
  • Meetings: One scheduled meeting per year, and unscheduled as needed.

7001.2 General Operating Guidelines

  • Agencies must have the capability to communicate with Medical Control to participate.
  • There are two types of drug bags: ALS/BLS (navy) and BLS only (red fanny-pack).
  • All drug bags are property of the GMVEMSC and are only for use by EMS providers within the GMVEMSC’s region.
  • Except in extreme circumstances, a drug bag should not be used on multiple runs.
  • There are initiation and annual maintenance fees for each bag.
  • Compartments are sealed with a blue plastic device by pharmacy. After use, the bag should be cleaned and re-sealed with the red plastic device found inside.
  • Non-compliance may result in notification of agency leadership, governing agencies, and ultimately, removal from the program.

7001.3 Participation Requirements

  • Active membership in the GMVEMS Council.
  • Provide at least one functioning email contact for the GMVEMSC Listserve and Agency Contacts list.
  • Submit the annual Attestation Form.
  • Provide a copy of the agency's drug license to the Council by March 31 of each renewal year.
  • Complete drug bag updates when scheduled.
  • Signed agreement to abide by the Drug Bag Exchange Program Operating Guidelines.
  • No participating department shall possess a DEA License.
  • Complete the GMVEMSC annual skills and written test between March 1 and May 31.
  • Maintain all drugs in a clean, temperature-controlled environment (59-86°F).
  • Required equipment must be available to utilize the drug bags.
  • Departments must have a system to track all drug bag exchanges.

7001.5 Three Strike Policy

  • An agency may be issued a strike for failure to comply with participation requirements.
  • The infraction will remain for a minimum of 1 year and will be reviewed for removal.
  • An agency can appeal an infraction with proper documentation.
  • If an agency reaches three strikes, they will be removed from the Drug Bag Program.

7001.6 Levels of Participation

  • Paramedic Level: Can access any compartment.
  • AEMT Level: Can access Airway, BLS, Intermediate, and Naloxone compartments. Cannot access the Center Inside Compartment.
  • EMT Level: Can only access the BLS Only fanny-pack, or the Airway, BLS, and Naloxone pouches of the ALS/BLS bag. Cannot access Intermediate and Center compartments.

title: Drug Bag Program: Wasted Drug Procedure
content:
7002.1 Guideline

  • Most hospitals require the GMVEMSC approved Controlled Drug Usage Form in addition to the run sheet.
  • This form must be filled out for any controlled drug use, even without wastage.
  • A completed run sheet must be provided to the hospital within 3 hours.

7002.2 Procedure

  • Fentanyl, Ketamine, Morphine, Versed and Valium are controlled drugs.
  • If a controlled medication from a GMVEMSC Drug Bag is partially administered, the unused portion must be accounted for.
  • When wasting, providers will waste the drug directly into a secure sharps container in the ambulance. Wasting into hospital sharps containers is not permitted.
  • Private organizations with different approved procedures may use them if they provide the policy in writing to GMVEMSC.
  • To ensure accountability, all paramedics and AEMTs will document:
    • The drug name
    • The amount used
    • The amount wasted (if none, list "none")
    • The specific location of the waste (e.g., "into sharps container")
    • The signature of a second witness if there is wastage (can be another crew member).

title: Drug Bag Program: Exchange Process
content:
7003.1 Guideline

  • Each department is assigned a "home" hospital for initial fulfillment and wholesale exchanges.
  • Drug bags can be exchanged at any participating hospital or within the same department.
  • ALS/BLS bags are exchanged for ALS/BLS bags; BLS for BLS. It is not permissible to exchange bags between different Fire/EMS Agencies.
  • The primary care provider is responsible for inventorying the drug bag before sealing it.
  • EMS personnel must complete the Sign In and Out log for exchanges. Each agency must also track exchanges internally.
  • The drug bag must be exchanged at the time of patient delivery, except for non-transports or transports to non-participating hospitals, in which case it must be exchanged within 8 hours.

7003.2 Drug Bag Seals

  • Blue Seals: Used by the pharmacy to seal restocked bags. They will have a hospital sticker identifying the hospital, pharmacist, and the next expiration date. EMS should verify the blue seal is intact before accepting a bag. When a compartment is opened, the blue seal must be retained and placed inside the compartment before resealing with a red tag.
  • Red Seals: Identify a used bag. EMS providers must inventory each opened pouch, clean it, and seal the used compartment with the red seal provided inside.

title: Drug Bag Program: Drug Bag Discrepancies
content:
7004.1 General Guidelines

  • EMS providers must inventory each opened pouch before applying the red seal.
  • All discrepancies must be reported to GMVEMSC using the Drug Bag Discrepancy Report.
  • If a discrepancy is found, notify an EMS Officer, retain the blue seal and sticker, log the bag in at the hospital, and inform the pharmacist or EMS Coordinator that a report is being initiated.

7004.2 Discrepancies Involving Controlled Drugs or Potential Tampering

  • If an issue with a controlled drug, stolen bag, or tampering cannot be resolved, specific reporting is required.
  • Notify your State of Ohio Board of Pharmacy agent immediately if theft is suspected.
  • Notify the Drug Bag Exchange Committee Chairs immediately.
  • File a report with law enforcement.
  • Notify the DEA within 24 hours using DEA Form 106.
  • Submit a completed GMVEMSC Drug Bag Discrepancy Report.

7004.3 Discrepancies Not Involving Controlled Drugs or Potential Tampering

  • Examples include missing non-controlled drugs, wrong doses, expired meds, empty vials, unsealed pouches, etc.
  • If discovered by EMS, the EMS Officer initiates the Discrepancy Form and provides copies to the Hospital EMS Coordinator and GMVEMSC.
  • If discovered by the Hospital, the EMS Coordinator initiates the form and submits it to GMVEMSC, notifying the responsible agency.

title: Drug Bag Program: Lost or Stolen Drug Bag Policy
content:
7005.1 Purpose

To provide a uniform mechanism for the investigation and reporting of lost or stolen drug bags.

7005.2 Notification

  • Upon discovery of a missing bag, agencies will notify the GMVEMSC Drug Bag Committee Chair(s).
  • Initiate the Drug Bag Discrepancy Form and follow reporting instructions.
  • The agency or the Committee Chair will notify the State of Ohio Board of Pharmacy (SOBP) at 614-466-4143.

7005.3 Investigation

  • The EMS agency shall implement an internal search (check scene, last hospital, wrong vehicle).
  • The GMVEMSC will assist by checking with all hospitals.
  • The GMVEMSC will coordinate with the assigned hospital for a replacement bag after all paperwork is submitted. A replacement fee will be assessed.

title: Drug Bag Program: Hospital Participation Policy
content:
7006.1 Purpose

To assure uniformity of hospital pharmacy participation in the Drug Bag Exchange Program.

7006.2 The Hospital Shall:

  • Purchase, fill, and maintain a sufficient supply of drug bags.
  • Accept responsibility for filling new drug bags for assigned departments.
  • Assign one licensed pharmacist and an EMS coordinator to participate in the committees.
  • Agree to pay annual dues and any assessed fees related to the program.

7006.3 The Greater Miami Valley EMS Council shall:

  • Maintain current State Drug Licenses for all participants.
  • Furnish hospital pharmacy with a current listing of all authorized departmental personnel.
  • Assign departments to hospitals in a geographic and equitable fashion.

title: Drug Bag Program: New Member Agency Policy
content:
7007.1 Purpose

To establish the procedures required for new agency members to receive a drug bag.

7007.2 Procedure:

Agencies needing a drug bag for OMTB inspection may request one 24 hours prior. To receive a bag, the agency must:

  • Have applied for GMVEMSC membership.
  • Provide a copy of their State Pharmacy License.
  • Have all agency personnel checked off on Standing Orders.
  • Have the Medical Director submit a notarized letter to the State Pharmacy Board approving use of the protocols.
  • Show proof of a temporary permit from the OMTB within 72 hours of inspection.

7007.3 Agreement Letter

An agency must provide a signed agreement letter to the GMVEMSC to participate in the program.

content:
7009.1 OAC 4729-9-15

(A) Each prescriber, terminal distributor, or wholesale distributor shall notify the following upon discovery of the theft or significant loss of any dangerous drug or controlled substance:

  1. The state board of pharmacy, by telephone immediately upon discovery;
  2. If a controlled substance, the DEA pursuant to section 1301.76(b), Code of Federal Regulations;
  3. Law enforcement authorities pursuant to section 2921.22 of the Revised Code.

(B) Controlled substance thefts must also be reported by using the Federal DEA Report form... A copy of the federal form...shall be filed with the State Board of Pharmacy within thirty days following the discovery of such theft or loss.

title: Ambulance Restocking Policy
content:
7010.1 History

  • In 1998, GDAHA received permission (Advisory Opinion No. 98.7) to exchange drugs and supplies with EMS agencies, avoiding violation of the anti-kickback statute.
  • In December 2001, the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services issued an Ambulance Final Rule on Ambulance Restocking Safe Harbor.

7010.2 EMS Supply Exchange Program:

  • EMS agencies must adhere to the agreement. For all transports to member hospitals, EMS agencies will provide copies of written records describing all medical supplies/medications used.
  • Participating hospitals will restock ambulances at no charge with the supplies/medications used during the transport to that receiving hospital.
  • Hospitals will not restock items used on patients delivered to another hospital.
  • Hospitals will restock drug bags.
  • Hospitals will not provide initial stock for new or returning ambulances.

title: Diversion of Emergency Patients
content:
7011.1 EMS and Dispatch Procedures:

  • When a hospital is on "Diversion of Emergency Patients," EMS should transport to hospitals in normal status to avoid jeopardizing patient care.
  • If a patient requests transport to a hospital on diversion, EMS must advise them that care may be jeopardized.

7011.2 Monitoring Emergency Department Status

  • Dispatch centers should monitor Juvare EMResources for hospital status changes and notify EMS units.

7011.3 Diversion Categories:

  • CLOSED: The hospital cannot accept any emergency patients due to an internal disaster or other situation. EMS will not transport to a CLOSED facility.
  • DIVERSION OF CERTAIN TYPES OF PATIENTS:
    • Limited Divert/Operations: The facility has limited ability to handle some situations (e.g., CT scanner downtime, no ICU beds).
    • Divert/At Capacity: The facility is at capacity and has paused inbound EMS traffic.

7011.4 Hospital and Satellite ED Procedures:

  • Hospitals will update Juvare EMResources with their status daily and whenever the status changes.
  • The diverting hospital must review and update its status hourly.

title: Infectious Disease Exposure Policy
content:
7014 Infectious Disease Exposure Reporting Policy

7014.1 General Guidelines

This policy provides public safety personnel and hospitals with standard guidelines for defining, responding to, and following up on an infection control exposure incident involving an emergency response provider.

7014.2 Blood-borne Exposure

  • Definition: A percutaneous injury (e.g., a needlestick or cut), or contact of mucous membrane or non-intact skin with blood, tissue, or other body fluids that are potentially infectious.
  • Post Exposure Procedure: Immediately irrigate the involved area. Report the exposure to the receiving hospital and a supervisor. The exposed employee must register as a patient at the same hospital as the source and complete the "Request for Information by Emergency Care Workers (RIECW)" form.
  • Testing The Source Patient: The hospital ED obtains patient consent and a blood specimen for HIV, HBV, and HCV testing. If the patient refuses consent, a hospital committee can authorize testing after a significant exposure.
  • Source Patient Results: HIV test results should be available within an hour. The exposed employee should remain in the ED until results are received. Written notification of positive results will be provided within 3 days.
  • Prophylaxis (PEP): Post-exposure prophylaxis may be offered based on a risk assessment. HIV PEP should be started as soon as possible. Hepatitis prophylaxis depends on the public safety worker's vaccine status. There is no prophylaxis for HCV.

7014.3 Respiratory Exposure

  • Definition: Contamination via airborne infectious agents (e.g., tuberculosis) or droplet infectious agents (e.g., meningitis, influenza).
  • Immediate Actions: Don PPE. If secretions are splashed into mucous membranes, flush with copious amounts of IV fluids. Notify the department Infection Control Officer (ICO) and the ED charge nurse, and complete the Request for Notification of Test form.
  • Source Patient Results: The hospital ICO will notify the department ICO of the infectious agent as soon as possible.

7014.4 Blood or Body Fluid & Airborne Exposures by Coroner’s Cases

  • Exposure during resuscitation: It is recommended that crews transport the patient to the hospital for source testing rather than following field termination procedures.
  • Actions of the ICO: The Coroner shall be notified as soon as possible that an exposure has occurred. A Request for Information form shall be forwarded to the Coroner's Office.
  • Testing the source patient: The Coroner shall make every effort to test a source patient by the next business day.

title: Adenosine
content:
Packaging

  • 6 mg (1 in drug bag) and 12 mg (2 in drug bag) prefilled syringes

Indications

  • Stable Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia (PSVT)

Adult Dosing

  • A 6 mg rapid IV as quickly as possible
  • If not successful, may repeat 12 mg rapid IV.
  • All doses of Adenosine are followed by 20 ml bolus of IV fluid.
  • Go directly to 12 mg if patient with history of PSVT advises it takes 12 mg. May repeat once.

Pediatric Dosing

  • 0.1 mg/kg rapid IV followed by 10 ml rapid saline flush. Max single dose 6 mg.
  • If unsuccessful, 0.2 mg/kg rapid IV followed by 10 ml rapid saline flush. Max single dose 12 mg. May repeat x one.

Therapeutic Action

  • Decreases electrical conduction through the AV node without causing negative inotropic effects
  • Acts directly on SA node to decrease chronotropic activity

Contraindications

  • Second or third degree AV block or sick sinus syndrome
  • Hypersensitivity to Adenosine

Precautions And Side Effects

  • Lightheadedness, Paresthesia, Headache, Diaphoresis, Palpitations, Chest pain, Hypotension
  • Shortness of breath, Transient periods of sinus bradycardia, sinus pause, or asystole
  • Ventricular ectopy, Nausea, Metallic taste.
  • May produce bronchoconstriction in patients with asthma and in patients with bronchopulmonary disease

Protocols

  • Cardiac Protocol 2011 - Tachycardia

title: Albuterol
content:
Packaging

  • 2.5 mg in 3 ml plastic ampule (4 in drug bag)

Indications

For the EMT, AEMT and Paramedic:

  • Exacerbation of Asthma, Emphysema, or COPD
  • Bronchospasm in Asthma, COPD
  • Allergic reaction with wheezing

For the Paramedic only:

  • Hyperkalemia in the presence of Crush Syndrome Trauma

Adult Dosing

  • 2.5 mg (3 ml), nebulized with O2 at 8-10 LPM.
  • Combine Ipratropium with first dose of Albuterol.
  • May repeat Albuterol up to 2 times for a total of 3 doses
  • Give all 4 doses for hyperkalemia
  • In Crush syndrome: administer 10 mg nebulized

Pediatric Dosing

  • 2.5 mg (3 ml), nebulized with O2 at 8-10 LPM.
  • Combine Ipratropium with first dose of Albuterol.
  • May repeat Albuterol up to 2 times for a total of 3 doses
  • In Crush syndrome: administer 10 mg nebulized

Therapeutic Action

  • Bronchodilator

Contraindications

  • Prior hypersensitive reaction to Albuterol
  • Cardiac dysrhythmias associated with tachycardia.

Precautions And Side Effects

  • Once initiated, the patient should be removed by EMS.
  • Side Effects: Restlessness, Apprehension, Dizziness, Palpitations, Tachycardia, Dysrhythmias
  • May precipitate angina pectoris

Protocols

  • General Protocol 1008-Advanced Airway Management
  • Medical Protocol 4002 - Allergic Reaction/Anaphylaxis
  • Medical Protocol 4003 - Asthma/Emphysema/COPD
  • Trauma Protocol 3007 - Crush Syndrome Trauma (Paramedic only)

title: Amiodarone
content:
Packaging

  • 150 mg in 3 ml vial, 50 mg/ml
  • 3 vials in drug bag

Indications

  • Ventricular Fibrillation or Pulseless Ventricular Tachycardia
  • Stable Wide-Complex Tachycardia

Adult Dosing

Ventricular Fibrillation or Pulseless Ventricular Tachycardia

  • 300 mg IV or IO.
  • May repeat with half the initial dose (150 mg IV or IO) no sooner than 10 minutes after first dose.
  • If patient converts with ROSC from a ventricular arrhythmia and no anti-arrhythmic has been given: 150 mg in 250 ml NS, IV wide open over 10 minutes using 60 gtt/ml tubing & 18 g angiocath

Stable Wide-Complex Tachycardia:

  • 150 mg in 250 ml NS, IV wide open over 10 minutes using 60 gtt/ml tubing & 18 g angiocath

Pediatric Dosing

Ventricular Fibrillation or Pulseless Ventricular Tachycardia

  • 5 mg/kg IV or IO (max first dose 300 mg).
  • May repeat 5 mg/kg IV or IO no sooner than 10 minutes after first dose. Max repeat dose is 150 mg
  • Not indicated for stable wide complex tachycardia

Therapeutic Action

  • Antidysrhythmic agent with multiple mechanisms of action

Contraindications

  • Pulmonary congestion
  • Cardiogenic shock
  • Hypotension (SBP less than 100)
  • Sensitivity to Amiodarone

Precautions And Side Effects

  • Continuous EKG monitoring is required.
  • Side Effects: Hypotension, Headache, Dizziness, Bradycardia, AV conduction abnormalities, Flushed skin, Abnormal salivation

Protocols

  • Cardiac Protocol 2005 - Cardiac Arrest: Ventricular Fib or Pulseless V-Tach
  • Cardiac Protocol 2011-Tachycardia

title: Aspirin
content:
Packaging

  • 81mg tablets in a blister pack (4 tablets total)

Indications

  • Given as soon as possible to the patient with AMI.

Adult Dosing

  • 324 mg chewed (Four 81 mg tablets)

Pediatric Dosing

  • Not applicable to pediatric patients

Therapeutic Action

  • Anti-platelet

Contraindications

  • Hypersensitivity to salicylates
  • Active ulcer disease
  • Bleeding disorders
  • Third trimester pregnancy

Precautions And Side Effects

  • Suspected cardiac chest pain must be at least 25 years old.
  • Patient must chew the tablets
  • Side Effects: Stomach irritation, Heartburn or indigestion, Nausea or vomiting, Allergic reactions

Protocols

  • Cardiac Protocol 2008 - Suspected Cardiac Chest Pain
  • Medical Protocol 4011-Obstetrical Emergencies

title: Atropine
content:
Packaging

  • 1mg in 10 ml prefilled syringe; (3 in drug bag)
  • In Haz Mat/WMD Security Bag: Duodote: 2 mg auto-injector (along with 2-Pam 600 mg autoinjector)
  • In WMD Drug Caches and Chempacks: 2 mg, 1mg and 0.5 mg AtroPen auto-injectors; Multidose vial 8 mg in 20 ml, 0.4 mg/ml

Indications

  • Symptomatic bradycardia
  • Organophosphate or Nerve Agent poisoning (regardless of cardiac rate)

Adult Dosing

  • Bradycardia: 1 mg IV up to 3 mg
  • Organophosphate or Nerve Gas poisoning: EMR, EMT, AEMT, Paramedic: 2 mg Duodote auto-injector. Paramedic only: 2 mg IV, IO or IM. No max dose, given every 5 min or until lungs are clear to auscultation.

Pediatric Dosing

  • Bradycardia: 0.02 mg/kg IV or IO every 5 min. Minimum single dose of 0.1 mg, max single dose 0.5 mg. Maximum total dose 1 mg
  • Organophosphate or Nerve Gas poisoning: For EMR, EMT, AEMT or Paramedic: Less than 20 kgs: 0.5 mg AtroPen auto-injector; 20-40 kgs: 1.0 mg AtroPen auto-injector; Greater than 40 kgs: 2.0 mg AtroPen auto-injector. Paramedic only: May give atropine doses listed IV or IM. No max dose, given every 5 minutes or until lungs are clear to auscultation.

Therapeutic Action

  • Anticholinergic

Contraindications

  • None for severe organophosphate exposure.
  • Tachycardia
  • Hypersensitivity to atropine
  • Obstructive disease of Gl tract
  • Obstructive neuropathy
  • Unstable cardiovascular status in acute hemorrhage with myocardial ischemia
  • Narrow angle glaucoma
  • Thyrotoxicosis

Precautions And Side Effects

  • EMR, EMT and AEMT can only administer the Duodote auto-injector to Organophosphate or Nerve Agent patients
  • Pupillary dilation rendering the pupils nonreactive. Pupil response may not be useful in monitoring CNS status.
  • Side Effects: Dysrhythmias, tachycardia, palpitations, Paradoxical bradycardia when pushed too slowly or when used at doses less than 0.5 mg, Headache or dizziness, Anticholinergic effects (dryness, photophobia, blurred vision, urinary retention, constipation), Nausea and vomiting, Flushed, hot, dry skin, Allergic reactions.

Protocols

  • Cardiac Protocol 2010-Bradycardia
  • Special Operations Protocol 6002-Antidote Resources
  • Special Operations Protocol 6005- Organophosphate or Nerve agent Exposure

title: Calcium Chloride
content:
Packaging

  • 1 gram in 10 ml vial, 100 mg/ml (1 in drug bag)

Indications

  • Renal dialysis patient in cardiac arrest or with bradycardia
  • Calcium Channel Blocker OD
  • Hydrofluoric Acid exposure with tetany or cardiac arrest. Tetany may present as: overactive neurological reflexes, spasms of the hands and feet, cramps, and laryngospasm.
  • May be given prophylactically, after exposure to high concentration (> 40%) Hydrofluoric Acid
  • Adults with Crush Syndrome presenting with abnormal ECG or hemodynamic instability

Adult Dosing

  • 1 gm (10 ml) IV for: Cardiac arrest in renal dialysis patients, Calcium Channel Blocker OD, Hydrofluoric Acid exposure with tetany or cardiac arrest
  • For prophylaxis in high concentration Hydrofluoric Acid exposure: 400 mg (4 ml) IV
  • Renal dialysis patient with bradycardia: 1 gm (10 ml) IV
  • Crush syndrome: 1 gm (10 ml) IV

Pediatric Dosing

  • 20 mg/kg IV (max dose 500 mg) for: Cardiac arrest in renal dialysis patients, Calcium Channel Blocker OD
  • Call in advance to treat crush syndrome or hydrofluoric acid exposures in pediatric patients

Therapeutic Action

  • Antagonizes cardiac toxicity in hyperkalemia associated with dialysis patients.
  • Reverses symptoms of Calcium Channel Blocker

Contraindications

  • None in the emergency setting

Precautions And Side Effects

  • Do not administer with Sodium Bicarbonate because if mixed, a precipitate develops. Flush tubing between drugs.
  • Side Effects: Bradycardia (may cause asystole), Hypotension, Metallic taste, Severe local necrosis and sloughing following IV infiltration, May produce vasospasm in coronary and cerebral arteries, Hypertension and bradycardia may occur with rapid administration.

Protocols

  • Cardiac Protocol 2004-Cardiac Arrest - Renal Failure/Dialysis
  • Cardiac Protocol 2010-Bradycardia
  • Trauma Protocol 3007 - Crush Syndrome Trauma
  • Medical Protocol 4012-Overdose or Poisoning
  • Special Operations Protocol 6004 - Hydrofluoric Acid Exposure

title: Calcium Gluconate
content:
Packaging

  • 1 gram in 10 ml vial, 100 mg/ml. Only in the drug bag in the event of Calcium Chloride 10% shortage

Indications

  • Renal dialysis patient in cardiac arrest or with bradycardia
  • Calcium Channel Blocker OD
  • Hydrofluoric Acid exposure with tetany or cardiac arrest.
  • Tetany may present as: overactive neurological reflexes, spasms of the hands and feet, cramps, and laryngospasm.
  • May be given prophylactically, after exposure to high concentration (> 40%) Hydrofluoric Acid
  • Adults with Crush Syndrome presenting with abnormal ECG or hemodynamic instability

Adult Dosing

  • 1 gm (10 ml) IV for: Cardiac arrest in renal dialysis patients, Calcium Channel Blocker OD, Hydrofluoric Acid exposure with tetany or cardiac arrest
  • For prophylaxis in high concentration Hydrofluoric Acid exposure: 400 mg (4 ml) IV
  • Renal dialysis patient with bradycardia: 1 gm (10 ml) IV
  • Crush syndrome: 1 gm (10 ml) IV

Pediatric Dosing

  • 20 mg/kg IV (max dose 500 mg) for: Cardiac arrest in renal dialysis patients, Calcium Channel Blocker OD
  • Call in advance to treat crush syndrome or hydrofluoric acid exposures in pediatric patients

Therapeutic Action

  • Antagonizes cardiac toxicity in hyperkalemia associated with dialysis patients.

content:

Indications

  • The EMR and the EMT cannot treat Asthma with Epinephrine

Adult Dosing

  • Asthma (AEMT and Paramedic) or Anaphylaxis (EMR, EMT, AEMT and Paramedic)
  • If equal to or greater than 30 kg, give both Adult EpiPen 0.3 mg and EpiPen Jr 0.15 mg
  • May repeat after 10 minutes

Pediatric Dosing

  • Asthma (AEMT and Paramedic) or Anaphylaxis (EMR, EMT, AEMT and Paramedic)
  • If less than 15 kg, EpiPen Jr 0.15 mg
  • If equal to or greater than 15 kg and less than 30 kg, Adult EpiPen 0.3 mg
  • If greater than 30 kg, give both Adult EpiPen 0.3 mg and EpiPen Jr 0.15 mg

Therapeutic Action

  • Directly stimulates alpha and beta adrenergic receptors in dose-related fashion
  • Causes bronchodilation, vasoconstriction, and increased cardiac output.

Contraindications

  • None in the emergency setting

Precautions And Side Effects

  • While the protocol lists those patients under 15 kg as pediatric, it is understood that patients equal to or greater than 30 kg will get both the Adult EpiPen and the EpiPen Jr., no matter what their age.
  • Epinephrine dosing for Asthma, Allergies and Anaphylaxis is based on weight, not age
  • Side Effects: Headache, Nausea, Restlessness, Weakness, Dysrhythmias, including ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation, Hypertension, Tachycardia, May increase myocardial oxygen demand or precipitation of angina pectoris, Syncope has occurred following epinephrine administration to asthmatic children.

title: Fentanyl
content:
Packaging

  • 100 mcg/2 ml (50 mcg/ml) vial
  • One in drug bag

Indications

  • Suspected Cardiac Chest Pain
  • Pain associated with traumatic events
  • Extremity Fractures
  • Dislocations or Sprains
  • Frostbite
  • Abdominal Pain
  • Hydrofluoric Acid (Hf) exposure

Adult Dosing

  • 50-100 mcg slow IV, provided SBP is greater than 100.
  • May repeat 50-100 mcg slow IV, after 5 minutes provided SBP greater than 100.
  • If no IV, Fentanyl 50-100 mcg IN, SQ or IM
  • May repeat Fentanyl 50-100 mcg IN, SQ or IM after 10 minutes
  • Patient greater than 69 y/o, reduce dosing for sedatives and analgesics to one half ( ) of the adult dose

Pediatric Dosing

  • Fentanyl is not to be administered to anyone less than 2 years of age.
  • If unable to obtain a blood pressure, look for evidence adequate perfusion prior to administration.
  • Contact MCP prior to treatment of abdominal pain
  • First choice treatment for pain: 1 mcg/kg IN, max dose 100 mcg., provided age appropriate normal SBP ( (80+2x age in years). Repeat 1 mcg/kg IN after 10 minutes, if an additional drug bag is available.
  • Second choice treatment for pain: 1 mcg/kg slow IV, max dose 100 mcg. Repeat 1 mcg/kg, slow IV after 5 minutes, max dose 100 mcg. Maintain age appropriate blood pressure
  • If unable to obtain IV: SQ or IM for pediatric patients is a last resort: 1 .mcg/kg SQ or IM, max dose 100 mcg. Repeat 1 1 mcg/kg SQ or IM, max dose 100 mcg, no sooner than 10 minutes after first dose.

Therapeutic Action

  • Provides analgesia
  • Reduces cardiac preload by increasing venous capacitance and decreasing afterload

Contraindications

  • Hypersensitivity

Precautions And Side Effects

  • Chest wall rigidity ("wooden chest syndrome") may occur: Prevents adequate chest wall excursion and ventilation. Typically occurs with high doses ( (6-7 mcg/kg) or with rapid administration. Reversible with naloxone.
  • Provide continuous cardiac monitoring, EtCO2 and pulse oximetry with sedated patients.
  • Geriatric & debilitated patients require lower doses & are more prone to side effects.
  • Apnea
  • CNS depression
  • Bradycardia which may be transient. Ensure adequate ventilation and oxygenation first. Atropine only if bradycardia is symptomatic and hemodynamically significant. For the Paramedic, follow bradycardia protocol.

content:

Mix: The vial should be inverted or rocked, not shaken, for at least 1 min. before infusion. Infuse Vial: Use vented intravenous tubing, hang and infuse over 15 minutes.
  • 5 gram vial via slow IV infusion over 15 minutes (Can be given IO as a last resort)

Therapeutic Action
